title: Quiz 1: Surgery FQE (Feb 2025)
description: Comprehensive Surgery Final Qualifying Examination from February 2025. Covers MCQs, Orthopaedics, Trauma, and General Surgery cases.

questions.question: Male circumcision is very essential medically, religiously and culturally. Which is the correct suturing technique in male circumcision?

options.text: Vertical mattress suturing dorsally, horizontal mattress ventrally and simple interrupted in between
Horizontal mattress ventrally, vertical mattress dorsally, and simple interrupted in between
Vertical mattress ventrally, horizontal mattress dorsally, and simple interrupted in between
Simple interrupted dorsally, horizontal mattress ventrally and vertical mattress in between

questions.explanation: Standard practice often involves a horizontal mattress suture at the frenulum (ventral side) to ensure hemostasis of the frenular artery, and simple interrupted sutures elsewhere. Some variations use vertical mattress dorsally to align the skin and mucosa.
questions.hint: Focus on the ventral side (frenulum) where hemostasis is critical.

questions.question: Development of decubitus is a possibility in bed ridden patients. Select the correct statement about decubitus ulcers.

options.text: Their development in spinal injury patient can be prevented by 4 hourly turning.
They respond well to application of topical antibiotics
Wound excision is a treatment modality
An ulcer with white base shows sign of healing

questions.explanation: The primary prevention strategy for pressure sores (decubitus ulcers) is frequent turning to relieve pressure. While '4 hourly' is stated in the option, standard care is often 2-hourly, but A is the only clinically viable preventative option listed. A white base often indicates slough/necrosis, not healing.
questions.hint: Think about prevention strategies for immobilized patients.

questions.question: Determine the correct statement regarding preoperative starvation.

options.text: After a short fast, insulin level falls
Muscle glycogen can be directly utilized
Fats are initially mobilized to meet energy requirements
Gluconeogenesis only takes place in the liver.

questions.explanation: During the early stages of starvation (e.g., preoperative fasting), insulin levels drop, and glucagon levels rise to facilitate glycogenolysis and lipolysis. Muscle glycogen cannot be directly converted to blood glucose.
questions.hint: Consider the hormonal changes that trigger energy mobilization when not eating.

questions.question: Regional anaesthesia is commonly used during surgical operations. Choose the correct response below:

options.text: Spinal anaesthesia is administered during caesarean sections.
Propofol is commonly used in regional anaesthesia
Reversal is achieved by administering atropine and neostigmine

questions.explanation: Spinal anaesthesia is a form of regional anaesthesia widely used for C-sections. Propofol is for general anaesthesia induction. Atropine/Neostigmine are for reversing neuromuscular blockade in GA.
questions.hint: Think about C-sections.

questions.question: A patient with third degree circumferential burns of the upper right forearm develops gross swelling of the right hand. Determine the correct statement concerning the patient.

options.text: Elevation of the limb is the definitive treatment modality
Infection is the most likely cause of the swelling

questions.explanation: Note: Both B and D are clinically correct in this scenario. Circumferential burns lead to eschar formation and compartment syndrome (B), which requires urgent escharotomy (D). In multiple choice logic, identifying the condition (Compartment Syndrome) is often the diagnostic step.
questions.hint: Circumferential burns act like a tourniquet.

questions.question: A 34 year old farmer suffered a cut wound on his left leg. After delaying medical services for 1 week, he developed darkening of the foot with loss of sensation. Determine the correct diagnosis.
questions.explanation: Darkening (blackening) and loss of sensation typically indicates gangrene. Dry gangrene presents with a clear line of demarcation and mummification.
questions.hint: Blackening and loss of sensation implies tissue death.

questions.question: When obtaining an informed consent, which statement is legally accurate?

options.text: The written communication material must always be in English.
Consent should be obtained by any staff involved in the operation
Every possible hazard, however remote, should be explained in detail.
Legally, a signed consent from a patient is proof that a valid consent has been properly obtained.

questions.explanation: Legally, the signed form serves as primary evidence of consent, though the *process* of understanding is clinically most important.
questions.hint: Think about the legal document itself.

questions.question: Arrange the correct order in the management of a degloving injury.
questions.explanation: The standard procedure is to debride devitalized tissue. If skin is viable, it is 'defatted' (turned into a full-thickness graft) and reapplied as a skin graft.
questions.hint: Clean the wound first, prepare the tissue, then cover.

questions.question: Regarding choledocholithiasis, select the correct statement below.

options.text: Surgery is always the treatment of choice
A positive Murphy's sign can be elicited
Unconjugated bilirubin will be elevated in the blood

questions.explanation: Choledocholithiasis often co-exists with cholecystitis (Murphy's sign). Obstruction causes CONJUGATED bilirubin elevation. Surgery isn't always choice (ERCP is common).
questions.hint: Think about associated gallbladder inflammation.

questions.question: Which of the following are considered immediate life-threatening conditions (The Lethal Six) in chest injuries? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The 'Lethal Six' includes: Airway obstruction, Tension pneumothorax, Cardiac tamponade, Open pneumothorax, Massive hemothorax, and Flail chest.
questions.hint: Focus on conditions that kill within minutes.

questions.question: Select the most common feature that distinguishes direct inguinal hernia from indirect inguinal hernia.

options.text: Indirect inguinal hernia does not descend to the scrotum
Strangulation is more likely to occur in direct inguinal hernia
Cough impulse is absent in direct inguinal hernia
Reducibility is readily observed when the patient lies down in direct inguinal hernia

questions.explanation: Direct hernias (through Hesselbach's triangle) have a wide neck and typically reduce spontaneously when the patient lies supine. Indirect hernias have a narrow neck and are prone to strangulation.
questions.hint: Direct hernias go straight back in.

questions.question: Post-operative apnoea and loss of voice after thyroidectomy is most commonly caused by:
questions.explanation: Bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerves causes vocal cord paralysis in the adducted position, leading to airway obstruction (apnoea) and loss of voice.
questions.hint: Which nerve runs directly behind the thyroid gland?

questions.question: A 46 year old male presents with recurrent diarrhoea alternating with constipation, blood stained mucoid stools, and weight loss. What is the most appropriate diagnostic investigation?
questions.explanation: Classic symptoms of Colorectal Cancer. Colonoscopy allows direct visualization and biopsy (histopathology), which is the gold standard for diagnosis.
questions.hint: Gold standard requires seeing the lesion and taking a sample.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions has an increased risk of breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Benign breast diseases with atypia (atypical hyperplasia) significantly increase the relative risk of developing breast cancer.
questions.hint: Look for the word 'atypical' or 'hyperplasia'.

questions.question: A 52 year old male presents with a long standing painless ulcer on the chin with indurated irregular edges and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the recommended management?

options.text: A biopsy for histopathology is a priority
Early surgical excision and biopsy for histopathology

questions.explanation: The description suggests Squamous Cell Carcinoma. Excision biopsy is diagnostic and therapeutic for smaller lesions; biopsy confirms malignancy.
questions.hint: Indurated, rolled edges usually mean malignancy.

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy presents with a swollen, painful right knee, pyrexia, and the knee held in flexion. What is the correct statement regarding management?

options.text: Arthrotomy and drainage is the definitive treatment modality
X-ray will show reduced joint space immediately
Immobilization with POP is highly recommended immediately

questions.explanation: This is Septic Arthritis. It is a surgical emergency requiring drainage (arthrotomy/washout) to prevent cartilage destruction. X-ray changes happen late.
questions.hint: Pus in a joint destroys cartilage rapidly.

questions.question: A 28 year old female has anal bleeding during defaecation and a protruding mass that disappears spontaneously after defaecation. What is the diagnosis/treatment?

options.text: Proctoscopy and biopsy are a priority
Sclerotherapy can be a treatment modality

questions.explanation: Symptoms describe 2nd Degree Hemorrhoids (prolapse but reduce spontaneously). Sclerotherapy or banding is appropriate. Manual reduction is for 3rd degree.
questions.hint: 2nd degree hemorrhoids reduce on their own.

questions.question: Calculate the Glasgow coma scale: Opens eyes to Pain, utters incomprehensible sounds, has decorticate posture.
questions.explanation: Eye (Pain) = 2; Verbal (Incomprehensible) = 2; Motor (Decorticate/Flexion) = 3. Total = 7.

questions.question: Concerning a patient with GCS 7/15, what is the priority?
questions.explanation: GCS 8 or less requires intubation to protect the airway ('GCS 8, intubate').
questions.hint: Airway protection is ABC priority.

questions.question: Patient with colicky pain on right loin radiating to RIF and blood stained urine. Determine the best management approach.

options.text: Request for abdominal CT scan takes precedence

questions.explanation: Classic ureteric colic. Non-contrast CT KUB is the gold standard investigation.
questions.hint: Gold standard imaging for stones.

questions.question: A newborn has cavus and plantar flexion deformities (Clubfoot). Establish the correct statement.

options.text: Immediate correction and splintage is required
Association with other congenital anomalies is rare
The condition is likely to heal spontaneously

questions.explanation: Congenital Talipes Equinovarus requires immediate serial manipulation and casting (Ponseti method).
questions.hint: Start treatment immediately after birth with casting.

questions.question: Regarding osteogenic sarcoma (Osteosarcoma), which statement is correct?

options.text: This condition is associated with Paget's disease of the bones

questions.explanation: Osteosarcoma has a bimodal peak; in the elderly, it is associated with Paget's disease. Onion peel is Ewing's.
questions.hint: Think about risk factors in older patients.

questions.question: Regarding rickets in a 3 year old, which statement is correct?

options.text: Bowing of legs is an early feature
Metaphyseal cupping and widening is a diagnostic radiological feature

questions.explanation: Radiological hallmarks of rickets are cupping, splaying, and fraying of metaphyses.
questions.hint: Look at the growth plates on X-ray.

questions.question: A 52-year-old with a humerus fracture treated for 4 months shows excessive mobility and no callus on X-ray. What is the diagnosis/treatment?
questions.explanation: Excessive mobility and no callus after 4 months indicates Non-Union (likely atrophic). Treatment is ORIF with bone grafting.
questions.hint: Atrophic non-union needs biological stimulation.

questions.question: Regarding stress fractures, which statement is true?

options.text: Easy to diagnose with radiographs early on
Heal at same rate as acute fractures
MRI is a useful adjunct in the diagnosis

questions.explanation: MRI is the gold standard for stress fractures as they are often invisible on X-ray for weeks.
questions.hint: Which scan sees edema in bone?

questions.question: Arrange the sequence of management for a suspected cervical spine injury (swimming pool accident).
questions.explanation: Immobilization is priority #1 to prevent cord damage. Then pain control, then imaging, then definitive traction.
questions.hint: Stabilize the neck first!

questions.question: Regarding Rheumatoid arthritis, which statement is correct?

options.text: Beta haemolytic streptococcus is the causative organism

questions.explanation: RA is an autoimmune disease treated with DMARDs and Biologics (Immunotherapy). It is systemic, not just joints.
questions.hint: It's an autoimmune disease.

questions.question: Management of osteoarthritis of the hip joint:

options.text: Early arthroplasty is recommended in young patients
NSAIDs are the first line pharmacological treatment

questions.explanation: NSAIDs provide symptom relief. Arthroplasty is delayed in young patients. Immobilization worsens stiffness.
questions.hint: Treat the pain and inflammation.

questions.question: A midline neck swelling that moves upward on protrusion of the tongue is most likely:
questions.explanation: Movement with tongue protrusion is pathognomonic for Thyroglossal cyst due to its connection to the foramen caecum.
questions.hint: Connected to the tongue base.

questions.question: Describe a Galeazzi fracture dislocation.

options.text: Fracture mid shaft ulna with dislocation of radial head
Fracture of radius with dislocation of distal radio-ulna joint
Fractures shafts of radius and ulna with dislocation radial head
Fractures shafts of radius and ulna with dislocation head of ulna

questions.explanation: Galeazzi = Radius fracture + Distal Radioulnar Joint (DRUJ) dislocation. (Monteggia is Ulna fx + Radial head dislocation).
questions.hint: GR = Galeazzi Radius.

questions.question: Fracture femur in adults is best managed by:
questions.explanation: Intramedullary Nailing (IMN) is the gold standard for adult femoral shaft fractures.
questions.hint: Fixation inside the canal.

questions.question: Regarding knee injuries, a positive Pivot shift sign signifies:
questions.explanation: Pivot Shift, Lachman's, and Anterior Drawer tests assess the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL).
questions.hint: Tests for rotational instability of the ACL.

questions.question: Order the management steps for hip dislocation.
questions.explanation: Reduce first, confirm stability/ROM clinically, confirm congruency radiologically, then maintain with traction.
questions.hint: Put it back, check it, hold it.

questions.question: Regarding Colles' fracture:

options.text: Rupture of extensor policis longus tendon is a late complication

questions.explanation: Colles' is dorsal displacement. EPL rupture is a known complication. It is usually treated with casting (CR+POP), not ORIF initially.
questions.hint: Tendon rupture happens weeks later.

questions.question: Regarding carotid body tumours:

options.text: Surgical excision is the treatment of choice
Preoperative biopsy is used to confirm
Presents as rapidly enlarging painful mass

questions.explanation: Biopsy is contraindicated due to vascularity. Surgery is the treatment. They are slow-growing and painless.
questions.hint: Do NOT biopsy this vascular tumor.

questions.question: Appropriate anaesthesia for a stable patient undergoing prostatectomy:
questions.explanation: Spinal anaesthesia is preferred for TURP/Prostatectomy to monitor for TURP syndrome and reduce bleeding.
questions.hint: Regional block allows monitoring mental status.

questions.question: A middle aged patient has a painless, cystic, trans-illuminating scrotal swelling. Select the correct statement.

options.text: Can be associated with testicular malignancy

questions.explanation: Hydroceles in young/middle-aged men can be secondary to testicular tumors. Aspiration recurs.
questions.hint: Always rule out underlying cause.

questions.question: Regarding carcinoma of the prostate:

options.text: Obliteration of medial sulcus is not suspicious
On DRE, the prostate feels irregular, stony hard, and indurated

questions.explanation: Hard, irregular, nodular prostate is classic for cancer. PSA is screening, biopsy confirms.
questions.hint: Stony hard gland.

questions.question: In VMMC, where is the horizontal mattress suture placed?
questions.explanation: Placed at the frenulum (6 o'clock ventral) to secure the frenular artery.
questions.hint: At the frenulum.

questions.question: In testicular torsion, which statement is true?

options.text: Doppler MUST be done before intervention
Fixation of the unaffected testis is recommended

questions.explanation: Bilateral orchidopexy is mandatory because the anatomical defect (bell clapper) is usually bilateral.
questions.hint: Fix both sides to prevent future torsion.

questions.question: Select the correct indications and complications of External Fixation. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: External fixation is used for severe open fractures and limb lengthening. Common complications involve the pin interface (infection, loosening).
questions.hint: Think about dirty wounds and pins going through skin.

questions.question: A 28-year-old man weighing 70 kg has 30% TBSA burns. Using the Parkland Formula (4mL x kg x %TBSA), calculate the total fluid volume for 24 hours (in mL).
questions.explanation: 4 mL x 70 kg x 30 = 8,400 mL.
questions.hint: 4 times weight times percentage.

questions.question: Case Study: 45yr old obese woman, RUQ pain, fever, positive Murphy's sign. Select the correct Diagnosis and Management steps. (Select all that apply)

richContent.content: Patient Case: 45yo Obese Female. RUQ pain radiating to back. Nausea/Vomiting. Fever 37.7C. Positive Murphy's Sign.

questions.explanation: Classic '4 Fs' presentation of Acute Cholecystitis. Diagnosed by US. Treated initially conservatively, then Cholecystectomy.
questions.hint: Fat, Female, Forty, Fertile, Fever.
